issue.title: [MNT] Upgrade prophet to >=1.1 and remove pystan from all_extras dependencies

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->

Closes https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2886

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

Upgrade `prophet` to `>=1.1` and remove `pystan` from `all_extras` dependencies.

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [X] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [X] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [MNT], [DOC], or [BUG] indicating whether the PR topic is related to enhancement, maintenance, documentation, or bug.

body: Hi, cmdstanpy maintainer here. Do you have any logs from the failure? Even if it’s not easily reproducible the error message might give us a place to start
@WardBrian Thanks for reaching out so quick! I think this would be a representative example: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/7106816665?check_suite_focus=true

Hi @WardBrian , thx that you look into it. Here is one of the logs from yesterday: https://pipelines.actions.githubusercontent.com/serviceHosts/4020a5b7-5870-47fe-a430-bbf53b49363a/_apis/pipelines/1/runs/23899/signedlogcontent/18?urlExpires=2022-06-29T12%3A57%3A13.8971983Z&urlSigningMethod=HMACV1&urlSignature=NE3ZS%2FBXgpq2Bp89yaSrhUIKArvq%2FxorOwPVO4Selfo%3D

You have to scroll to the end, there is some `RecursionError` happening: 
```
2022-06-28T20:51:43.0028705Z /opt/hostedtoolcache/Python/3.8.13/x64/lib/python3.8/site-packages/cmdstanpy/stanfit/mle.py:56: in __getattr__
2022-06-28T20:51:43.0029163Z     return self.stan_variable(attr)
2022-06-28T20:51:43.0029486Z E   RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded
2022-06-28T20:51:43.0029851Z         attr       = '_metadata'
2022-06-28T20:51:43.0030404Z         self       = <[RecursionError('maximum recursion depth exceeded') raised in repr()] CmdStanMLE object at 0x7f2c21a4f760>
2022-06-28T20:51:43.0030810Z !!! Recursion detected (same locals & position)
```

It seems like the change to support `.` for variable access made CmdStanPy objects un-pickleable. This should be fixable, but my more general question is if this is necessary behavior for cmdstanpy objects (and things which hold references to them, like Prophet objects)

Yeah you can reproduce this by trying to copy a fitted Prophet model (which has the CmdStanMLE saved in `m.stan_fit`).

```python
# cmdstanpy==1.0.1

from prophet import Prophet
import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/facebook/prophet/main/examples/example_wp_log_peyton_manning.csv')
m_fitted = Prophet().fit(df)
import copy
m_fitted_copy = copy.deepcopy(m_fitted)
```

```python
# cmdstanpy==1.0.2

from prophet import Prophet
import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/facebook/prophet/main/examples/example_wp_log_peyton_manning.csv')
m_fitted = Prophet().fit(df)
import copy
m_fitted_copy = copy.deepcopy(m_fitted)

~/.local/share/virtualenvs/cp37-Uo1qYR6O/lib/python3.7/site-packages/cmdstanpy/stanfit/mle.py in __getattr__(self, attr)
     54         """Synonymous with ``fit.stan_variable(attr)"""
     55         try:
---> 56             return self.stan_variable(attr)
     57         except ValueError as e:
     58             # pylint: disable=raise-missing-from

RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded
```

In the Prophet docs we already advise against pickling stan backend objects: https://facebook.github.io/prophet/docs/additional_topics.html#saving-models but I guess `copy` is a common action that people don't associate with pickling and expect to "just work".

yes its required that its `pickle`-able. In deployment of ML models, its common that `pickle` is used to dump models e.g. by means of `mlflow`. We also have tests to assure our models work well with `pickle`.
@fkiraly do we actually have a dedicated test for `deepcopy()`? Might be handy to have it

issue.title: Ensure stanfit objects can be deepcopied and pickled

repository.name: cmdstanpy
repository.description: CmdStanPy is a lightweight interface to Stan for Python users which provides the necessary objects and functions to compile a Stan program and fit the model to data using CmdStan.

issue.body:
#### Submission Checklist

- [x] Run unit tests
- [x] Declare copyright holder and open-source license: see below

#### Summary

The change in #543 broke the ability to pickle models. Because pickling does not call `__init__` on object, its internal state may not be 100% correct. 

This led to an infinite recursion in our `__getattr__` logic: `__getattr__` would call `stan_variable`, which would check `self._metadata`, which would call `__getattr__`. Luckily it is easy to fix this, since Stan variable names are forbidden from starting with an _

This is important for downstream packages like prophet, and sktime: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2898

As a result I would like to release 1.0.3 as soon as this is merged.

#### Copyright and Licensing

Please list the copyright holder for the work you are submitting (this will be you or your assignee, such as a university or company):



By submitting this pull request, the copyright holder is agreeing to license the submitted work under the following licenses:
- Code: BSD 3-clause (https://opensource.org/licenses/BSD-3-Clause)

body:
Thanks for the thorough report and explanation. I've just opened a PR to cmdstanpy which should fix this issue and tests the pickling of cmdstanpy objects going forward. Once it has passing tests and approval I plan to release a 1.0.3 just to address this.

I should note that cmdstanpy _cannot_ support _full_ pickling - certain operations like `.summary()` rely on the existence of files on disk which are outside the control of the pickling process. But, it seems like the most common operations, such as accessing the draws of the fit, do pickle fine, which is presumably all Prophet cares about in the end.

issue.title: Pin `cmdstanpy` in `diviner` tests

labels.name: rn/none
labels.description: List under Small Changes in Changelogs.

labels.name: enable-dev-tests
labels.description: Enables cross-version tests for dev versions

repository.name: mlflow
repository.description: Open source platform for the machine learning lifecycle

issue.body: Signed-off-by: harupy ## Related Issues/PRs #xxx ## What changes are proposed in this pull request? `prophet==1.1` is not compatible with `cmdstanpy==1.0.2`. To avoid this problem, pin `cmdstanpy`. See https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2898 for more details. #### Failure log https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/runs/7106976579?check_suite_focus=true#step:12:2442 ``` /opt/hostedtoolcache/Python/3.7.12/x64/lib/python3.7/site-packages/cmdstanpy/stanfit/mle.py:56: in __getattr__ return self.stan_variable(attr) attr = '__setstate__' self = <[RecursionError('maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object') raised in repr()] CmdStanMLE object at 0x7ff78a965d90> /opt/hostedtoolcache/Python/3.7.12/x64/lib/python3.7/site-packages/cmdstanpy/stanfit/mle.py:193: in stan_variable if var not in self._metadata.stan_vars_dims: inc_iterations = False self = <[RecursionError('maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object') raised in repr()] CmdStanMLE object at 0x7ff78a965d90> var = '__setstate__' warn = True /opt/hostedtoolcache/Python/3.7.12/x64/lib/python3.7/site-packages/cmdstanpy/stanfit/mle.py:56: in __getattr__ return self.stan_variable(attr) attr = '_metadata' self = <[RecursionError('maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object') raised in repr()] CmdStanMLE object at 0x7ff78a965d90> /opt/hostedtoolcache/Python/3.7.12/x64/lib/python3.7/site-packages/cmdstanpy/stanfit/mle.py:193: in stan_variable if var not in self._metadata.stan_vars_dims: inc_iterations = False self = <[RecursionError('maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object') raised in repr()] CmdStanMLE object at 0x7ff78a965d90> var = '_metadata' warn = True /opt/hostedtoolcache/Python/3.7.12/x64/lib/python3.7/site-packages/cmdstanpy/stanfit/mle.py:56: in __getattr__ return self.stan_variable(attr) E RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded ``` ## How is this patch tested? - [x] I have written tests (not required for typo or doc fix) and confirmed the proposed feature/bug-fix/change works. ## Does this PR change the documentation? - [x] No. You can skip the rest of this section. - [ ] Yes. Make sure the changed pages / sections render correctly by following the steps below. 1. Check the status of the `ci/circleci: build_doc` check. If it's successful, proceed to the next step, otherwise fix it. 2. Click `Details` on the right to open the job page of CircleCI. 3. Click the `Artifacts` tab. 4. Click `docs/build/html/index.html`. 5. Find the changed pages / sections and make sure they render correctly. ## Release Notes ### Is this a user-facing change? - [ ] No. You can skip the rest of this section. - [ ] Yes. Give a description of this change to be included in the release notes for MLflow users. (Details in 1-2 sentences. You can just refer to another PR with a description if this PR is part of a larger change.) ### What component(s), interfaces, languages, and integrations does this PR affect? Components - [ ] `area/artifacts`: Artifact stores and artifact logging - [ ] `area/build`: Build and test infrastructure for MLflow - [ ] `area/docs`: MLflow documentation pages - [ ] `area/examples`: Example code - [ ] `area/model-registry`: Model Registry service, APIs, and the fluent client calls for Model Registry - [x] `area/models`: MLmodel format, model serialization/deserialization, flavors - [ ] `area/pipelines`: Pipelines, Pipeline APIs, Pipeline configs, Pipeline Templates - [ ] `area/projects`: MLproject format, project running backends - [ ] `area/scoring`: MLflow Model server, model deployment tools, Spark UDFs - [ ] `area/server-infra`: MLflow Tracking server backend - [ ] `area/tracking`: Tracking Service, tracking client APIs, autologging Interface - [ ] `area/uiux`: Front-end, user experience, plotting, JavaScript, JavaScript dev server - [ ] `area/docker`: Docker use across MLflow's components, such as MLflow Projects and MLflow Models - [ ] `area/sqlalchemy`: Use of SQLAlchemy in the Tracking Service or Model Registry - [ ] `area/windows`: Windows support Language - [ ] `language/r`: R APIs and clients - [ ] `language/java`: Java APIs and clients - [ ] `language/new`: Proposals for new client languages Integrations - [ ] `integrations/azure`: Azure and Azure ML integrations - [ ] `integrations/sagemaker`: SageMaker integrations - [ ] `integrations/databricks`: Databricks integrations ### How should the PR be classified in the release notes? Choose one: - [ ] `rn/breaking-change` - The PR will be mentioned in the "Breaking Changes" section - [x] `rn/none` - No description will be included. The PR will be mentioned only by the PR number in the "Small Bugfixes and Documentation Updates" section - [ ] `rn/feature` - A new user-facing feature worth mentioning in the release notes - [ ] `rn/bug-fix` - A user-facing bug fix worth mentioning in the release notes - [ ] `rn/documentation` - A user-facing documentation change worth mentioning in the release notes

body: Would someone be able to run the sktime tests with the current `develop` branch of cmdstanpy? I'd like to confirm all downstream issues here are resolved before releasing the 1.0.3 patch

@WardBrian 
I have tested on `develop` of `cmdstanpy` and `main` of `sktime` with adjustment of removing the `cmdstanpy` requirement: It has passed! To test I used `pytest -k "Prophet"` which is testing all tests that run on `Prophet` class.

However I get a weird logging error after tests have passed:
```
=============================== 211 passed, 3 skipped, 30349 deselected, 18 warnings in 311.75s (0:05:11) ================================ 
--- Logging error ---
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Users\miniconda3\envs\cmdstanpy37\lib\logging\__init__.py", line 985, in emit
    stream.write(msg)
ValueError: I/O operation on closed file.
Call stack:
  File "C:\Users\miniconda3\envs\cmdstanpy37\lib\site-packages\cmdstanpy\__init__.py", line 31, in _cleanup_tmpdir
    logging.getLogger('cmdstanpy').info('deleting tmpfiles dir: %s', _TMPDIR)
Message: 'deleting tmpfiles dir: %s'
Arguments: ('C:\\Users\\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\tmpwnauoazq',)
--- Logging error ---
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Users\miniconda3\envs\cmdstanpy37\lib\logging\__init__.py", line 985, in emit
    stream.write(msg)
ValueError: I/O operation on closed file.
Call stack:
  File "C:\Users\miniconda3\envs\cmdstanpy37\lib\site-packages\cmdstanpy\__init__.py", line 31, in _cleanup_tmpdir
    logging.getLogger('cmdstanpy').info('deleting tmpfiles dir: %s', _TMPDIR)
Message: 'deleting tmpfiles dir: %s'
Arguments: ('C:\\Users\\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\tmpwnauoazq',)
--- Logging error ---
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Users\miniconda3\envs\cmdstanpy37\lib\logging\__init__.py", line 985, in emit
    stream.write(msg)
ValueError: I/O operation on closed file.
Call stack:
  File "C:\Users\miniconda3\envs\cmdstanpy37\lib\site-packages\cmdstanpy\__init__.py", line 33, in _cleanup_tmpdir
    logging.getLogger('cmdstanpy').info('done')
Message: 'done'
Arguments: ()
--- Logging error ---
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Users\miniconda3\envs\cmdstanpy37\lib\logging\__init__.py", line 985, in emit
    stream.write(msg)
ValueError: I/O operation on closed file.
Call stack:
  File "C:\Users\miniconda3\envs\cmdstanpy37\lib\site-packages\cmdstanpy\__init__.py", line 33, in _cleanup_tmpdir
    logging.getLogger('cmdstanpy').info('done')
Message: 'done'
Arguments: ()
2022-06-29 21:41:27,622 - prophet - INFO - Disabling weekly seasonality. Run prophet with weekly_seasonality=True to override this.        
2022-06-29 21:41:27,632 - prophet - INFO - Disabling daily seasonality. Run prophet with daily_seasonality=True to override this.
```

Yeah, that’s an unrelated but annoying bug in Pytest: https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/5502

At CmdStanPy we could work around it by either not logging that we’ve cleaned up temp files, or doing this logging with print statements, both of which have drawbacks

issue.title: [MNT] Remove `cmdstanpy` from `all_extras`

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->

closes #2898 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

Remove `cmdstanpy` from `all_extras` since it is installed as a direct dependency of `prophet`.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

No

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [X] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [X] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [MNT], [DOC], or [BUG] indicating whether the PR topic is related to enhancement, maintenance, documentation, or bug.
